net.derquinse.common.meta

Class MetaProperty<C,T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.derquinse.common.meta.MetaField<C,T>
      • net.derquinse.common.meta.MetaProperty<C,T>
  • Type Parameters:
    C - Containing type.
    T - Property type.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Function<C,T>, WithMetaClass, WithNameProperty, WithRequiredFlag
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ByteStringMetaProperty, ComparableMetaProperty

    public abstract class MetaProperty<C,T>
extends MetaField<C,T>
implements WithRequiredFlag, Function<C,T>
    Base class for property descriptors.
    Author:
    Andres Rodriguez

      • isNull

      • notNull

        public final Predicate<C> notNull()
        Returns a predicate that evaluates to true if the property value being tested is not null.

      • equalTo

        public final Predicate<C> equalTo(@Nullable
                   T target)
        Returns a predicate that evaluates to true if the property value equals() the given target or both are null.

      • sameAs

        public final Predicate<C> sameAs(@Nullable
                  T target)
        Returns a predicate that evaluates to true if the property value is the same (identity equality) as the given target or both are null.

      • instanceOf

        public final Predicate<C> instanceOf(Class<?> clazz)
        Returns a predicate that evaluates to true if the property value tested is an instance of the given class. If the property value being tested is null this predicate evaluates to false.

        Warning: contrary to the typical assumptions about predicates (as documented at Predicate.apply(T)), the returned predicate may not be consistent with equals. For example, instanceOf(ArrayList.class) will yield different results for the two equal instances Lists.newArrayList(1) and Arrays.asList(1).

      • in

        public final Predicate<C> in(Collection<? extends T> target)
        Returns a predicate that evaluates to true if the property value being tested is a member of the given collection. It does not defensively copy the collection passed in, so future changes to it will alter the behavior of the predicate. This method can technically accept any Collection, but using a typed collection helps prevent bugs. This approach doesn't block any potential users since it is always possible to use Predicates.<Object>in().
        Parameters:
        target - The collection that may contain the property value.
